content.title: Dimensionless vs Dimensional Constants
content.summary: The fundamental difference between dimensionless constants (like the fine-structure constant α ≈ 1/137) and dimensional constants (like c, ℏ, G). Only dimensionless constants represent true physics, while dimensional constants depend on our choice of units.

dimensional_constants.definition: Constants whose numerical value depends on the choice of units
dimensional_constants.key_point: These are really conversion factors between our arbitrary unit systems, not fundamental numbers
dimensional_constants.analogy: Like exchange rates between currencies - they tell us how our measurement systems relate

dimensionless_constants.definition: Pure numbers with no units, whose value is independent of measurement conventions
dimensionless_constants.key_point: These encode actual physics - the relative strengths and scales that nature chooses
dimensionless_constants.analogy: Like the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter (π) - true in any units

for_physics: Only dimensionless ratios can appear in fundamental theory
Dimensional constants can always be set to 1 by choice of units
The 'true' constants of nature are ratios like α, m_e/m_P, etc.
for_planck_units: Setting c = ℏ = G = 1 is choosing a natural system of units
Does NOT change any physics, just simplifies notation
Remaining dimensionless numbers (α, mass ratios) encode all physics
for_fundamental_questions: Why is α ≈ 1/137? (anthropic, dynamical, or random?)
Could these numbers be different in other universes?

conversion_factors.role: Define relationships between SI units and natural units

coupling_constants.status: Truly fundamental, could have been different

philosophical_depth.question: If all physics is encoded in ~25 dimensionless numbers (Standard Model parameters), why these specific values?
